paper_title: Boosting photocatalytic CO2 reduction over a covalent organic framework decorated with ruthenium nanoparticles
source: In the current work, Ru nanoparticles (NPs) loaded ketoaminebased COF (TpPa-1) catalysts, named Ru/TpPa-1, were developed for the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 upon visible-light irradiation for the first time.
context: The conversion of CO 2 into valuable chemicals utilizing solar energy is one of the most promising approaches to solve the problems associated with global warming and energy shortage.Considering more and more covalent organic frameworks (COFs) that have been reported, the great potential of COFs as photocatalysts for CO 2 reduction is still appreciated to a limited extent.In the current work, Ru nanoparticles (NPs) loaded ketoaminebased COF (TpPa-1) catalysts, named Ru/TpPa-1, were developed for the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 upon visible-light irradiation for the first time.Compared with TpPa-1, Ru/TpPa-1 catalysts exhibit a significantly enhanced activity for the photoreduction of CO 2 .In combination with the results from some extensive characterizations, it is found that the interactions between the Ru NPs and TpPa-1 can enhance the visible-light harvesting and create a new way to extend the service life of photo-generated charge carriers via facilitating the electron transfer through the loaded Ru NPs.The current investigation, therefore, provides a photocatalytic approach for CO 2 fixation, enriches the theory of photocatalysis, and enlarges the application of COF-based materials.

paper_title: Boosting photocatalytic CO2 reduction over a covalent organic framework decorated with ruthenium nanoparticles
source: The Ru-loaded TpPa-1 samples were prepared through solution infiltration of the activated TpPa-1 (49 mg) with 0.2, 0.6, and mL of RuCl 3 methanol solution (5 g L -1 ), respectively.
context: All reagents with an analytical grade were used as received without further purification.1,3,5-Triformylphloroglucinol were purchased from Hangzhou Yuhao Chemical Technology Co., Ltd.p-Phenylenediamine, mesitylene, o-dichlorobenzene, 1,4-dioxane, and ruthenium chloride (RuCl 3 ) were purchased from Shanghai Bailingwei Technology Co., Ltd.Anhydrous methanol and anhydrous sodium carbonate (Na 2 CO 3 ) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Technology Co., Ltd.Acetic acid, acetonitrile (MeCN), triethanolamine (TEOA), tetrahydrofuran, dichloromethane, acetone, and sodium sulfate(Na 2 SO 4 ) were purchased from Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. TpPa-1.A 4 mL Pyrex tube was charged with 1,3,5-triformylphloroglucinol (42 mg) and p-phenylenediamine (32 mg) in 2.35 mL of a 1:1:0.3(volume ratio) solution of 1,4-dioxane, mesitylene, and aqueous acetic acid (3 mol L -1 ).The mixture was sonicated until the raw materials were completely dissolved.The tube was placed in a glove box, evacuated, and then sealed.The reaction was maintained at 120 C for 72 h to obtain a red solid at the bottom of the tube.The red precipitate was then collected by filtration and washed with acetone, dichloromethane, and tetrahydrofuran, respectively.Finally, the solid sample was dried under vacuum at 120 C for 12 h to obtain the activated TpPa-1. Ru/TpPa-1.The Ru-loaded TpPa-1 samples were prepared through solution infiltration of the activated TpPa-1 (49 mg) with 0.2, 0.6, and mL of RuCl 3 methanol solution (5 g L -1 ), respectively.The mixture was stirred for 12 h, then filtered, and dried at 80 C for 5 h, followed by the treatment in flowing H 2 and N 2 mixed gas (volume ratio 9:1) with a total rate of 50 mL (NTP) min -1 (NTP: room temperature and 101.3 kPa) at 280 C for 6 h.The resultant powder was thoroughly washed with deionized water and dried under N 2 atmosphere at 60 C for 10 h to obtain Ru/TpPa-1 samples.The nominal loaded amounts of Ru onto TpPa-1 were 1.0, 3.0, and 5.0 wt, named 1.0 wt Ru/TpPa-1, 3.0 wt Ru/TpPa-1, and 5.0 wt Ru/TpPa-1, respectively. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker) using Cu K radiation ( 0.1541 nm) in the scanning range of 4-50 .The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet NEXUS670 spectrometer (ThermoFisher) with a resolution of 4 cm -1 .The textural properties of the prepared samples were determined by N 2 adsorption at -196 C using an ASAP 2020 apparatus (Micromeritics Instrument Corp.).The specific surface areas, S BET and S Langmuir , were calculated using the multiple-point Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir isotherm methods, respectively.The total pore volumes, V total , were calculated from the adsorbed amounts in the adsorption branches at a relative pressure of p/p 0 0.97.The scanning electron microscope (SEM) was carried out on an S-4800 apparatus (Hitachi) equipped with a field emission gun.The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was conducted on a JEOL JEM-1200 working at kV.The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on Thermo Scientific EscaLab 250Xi using Al K radiation (ThermoFisher).The UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS) were recorded on a Nicolet Evolution 500 Spectrophotometer (ThermoFisher) with BaSO as reflectance standard from 200 to 800 nm.The 13 C nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) was carried out on a Bruker AVANCE III 500 M system (500 MHz).The isotopic 13 CO 2 reduction was performed in an NMR tube filled with the photocatalyst in a CD 3 CN/TEOA (5:1 in volume ratio) solution.The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were recorded on an F-7000 spectrometer (Hitachi) excited at 326 nm.The time-resolved PL spectra of the samples at 480 nm emission were recorded with an Edinburgh FLS980 spectrophotometer at an excitation wavelength of 350 nm.The electrochemical measurements were carried out with a CHI760E workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Instruments Co.) in a conventional three-electrode cell using a Pt plate and an Ag/AgCl electrode as the counter electrode and a reference electrode, respectively.The photocatalyst powder (3 mg) deposited on the fluoride tin oxide (FTO) substrate glass was employed as the working electrode.The electrolyte was a 0.5 mol L -1 aqueous solution of Na 2 SO 4 without additive and was purged with N 2 gas for 1 h prior to the measurements.A 300 W PLS-SXE 300D Xenon lamp (Beijing Perfectlight) system was applied as the excitation light source equipped with a UV cutoff filter and an IR-cut filter, which was the same light source for the photocatalytic reaction.The Mott-Schottky curves were measured at a frequency of 200, 500, or 800 Hz, respectively. The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction was performed in an on-line CO 2 reduction system (Beijing Perfect Light Technology Co., Ltd.).Typically, 15 mg of the photocatalyst was added into the reaction flask, degassed and purged with CO 2 .A mixture of MeCN and TEOA (110 mL in total) with a volume ratio of 10 to 1 was degassed by CO 2 to remove the dissolved O 2 , and then injected into the reaction flask.The reaction proceeded under the irradiation of a Xe lamp (300 W) with a UV-cut filter and an IR-cut filter (800 nm 420 nm) at room temperature for 10 h.The formed HCOOH was detected by an ion chromatography (930 Compact IC pro, Metrohm) with a Metrosep A supp 5 250/4.0column.A mixture of 3.2 mM Na 2 CO 3 and 1.0 mM NaHCO 3 was used as eluent.The gaseous reaction products were also analyzed using a GC (Agilent 6890A) with a HP-5 capillary column for a flame ionization detector (FID) and a 5A molecular sieve packed column for a thermal conductivity detector (TCD).For the reusability test, after the reaction, the photocatalyst was separated from the reaction medium, repeatedly washed with deionized water twice, and then dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 120 C before the next run.

paper_title: Boosting photocatalytic CO2 reduction over a covalent organic framework decorated with ruthenium nanoparticles
source: All Ru/TpPa-1 photocatalysts show significantly enhanced activities for CO 2 reduction compared to the parent TpPa-1, giving the maximum HCOOH production rate of 108.8 mol g cat -1 h -1 over 3.0 wt Ru/TpPa-1 and competitive with some representative MOF-based photocatalysts under similar conditions.
context: In summary, the ketoamine-based COF (TpPa-1) loaded with different amounts of Ru NPs, Ru/TpPa-1, was employed in the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 using TEOA as the sacrificial agent upon visible-light irradiation for the first time.All Ru/TpPa-1 photocatalysts show significantly enhanced activities for CO 2 reduction compared to the parent TpPa-1, giving the maximum HCOOH production rate of 108.8 mol g cat -1 h -1 over 3.0 wt Ru/TpPa-1 and competitive with some representative MOF-based photocatalysts under similar conditions.The introduction of Ru NPs can not only enhance the visible-light absorption but also facilitate the photo-generated charge transfer and restrain the recombination of photo-generated charges efficiently.This study demonstrates the great potential of COFs as a platform for effectively photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.Although the activity of Ru/TpPa-1 is still not satisfied, considering the availability of different organic linkers and the possibility to modulate the composition, structure, and properties of COFs, high-efficient COFs-based photocatalysts for the reduction of CO 2 can be developed in the future.And the present strategy provides some guidance in the development of more efficiently heterogeneous photocatalysts for CO 2 reduction. TpPa-1.A 4 mL Pyrex tube was charged with 1,3,5-triformylphloroglucinol (42 mg) and p-phenylenediamine (32 mg) in 2.35 mL of a 1:1:0.3(volume ratio) solution of 1,4-dioxane, mesitylene, and aqueous acetic acid (3 mol L -1 ).The mixture was sonicated until the raw materials were completely dissolved.The tube was placed in a glove box, evacuated, and then sealed.The reaction was maintained at 120 C for 72 h to obtain a red solid at the bottom of the tube.The red precipitate was then collected by filtration and washed with acetone, dichloromethane, and tetrahydrofuran, respectively.Finally, the solid sample was dried under vacuum at 120 C for 12 h to obtain the activated TpPa-1. Ru/TpPa-1.The Ru-loaded TpPa-1 samples were prepared through solution infiltration of the activated TpPa-1 (49 mg) with 0.2, 0.6, and mL of RuCl 3 methanol solution (5 g L -1 ), respectively.The mixture was stirred for 12 h, then filtered, and dried at 80 C for 5 h, followed by the treatment in flowing H 2 and N 2 mixed gas (volume ratio 9:1) with a total rate of 50 mL (NTP) min -1 (NTP: room temperature and 101.3 kPa) at 280 C for 6 h.The resultant powder was thoroughly washed with deionized water and dried under N 2 atmosphere at 60 C for 10 h to obtain Ru/TpPa-1 samples.The nominal loaded amounts of Ru onto TpPa-1 were 1.0, 3.0, and 5.0 wt, named 1.0 wt Ru/TpPa-1, 3.0 wt Ru/TpPa-1, and 5.0 wt Ru/TpPa-1, respectively. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker) using Cu K radiation ( 0.1541 nm) in the scanning range of 4-50 .The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet NEXUS670 spectrometer (ThermoFisher) with a resolution of 4 cm -1 .The textural properties of the prepared samples were determined by N 2 adsorption at -196 C using an ASAP 2020 apparatus (Micromeritics Instrument Corp.).The specific surface areas, S BET and S Langmuir , were calculated using the multiple-point Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir isotherm methods, respectively.The total pore volumes, V total , were calculated from the adsorbed amounts in the adsorption branches at a relative pressure of p/p 0 0.97.The scanning electron microscope (SEM) was carried out on an S-4800 apparatus (Hitachi) equipped with a field emission gun.The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was conducted on a JEOL JEM-1200 working at kV.The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on Thermo Scientific EscaLab 250Xi using Al K radiation (ThermoFisher).The UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS) were recorded on a Nicolet Evolution 500 Spectrophotometer (ThermoFisher) with BaSO as reflectance standard from 200 to 800 nm.The 13 C nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) was carried out on a Bruker AVANCE III 500 M system (500 MHz).The isotopic 13 CO 2 reduction was performed in an NMR tube filled with the photocatalyst in a CD 3 CN/TEOA (5:1 in volume ratio) solution.The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were recorded on an F-7000 spectrometer (Hitachi) excited at 326 nm.The time-resolved PL spectra of the samples at 480 nm emission were recorded with an Edinburgh FLS980 spectrophotometer at an excitation wavelength of 350 nm.The electrochemical measurements were carried out with a CHI760E workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Instruments Co.) in a conventional three-electrode cell using a Pt plate and an Ag/AgCl electrode as the counter electrode and a reference electrode, respectively.The photocatalyst powder (3 mg) deposited on the fluoride tin oxide (FTO) substrate glass was employed as the working electrode.The electrolyte was a 0.5 mol L -1 aqueous solution of Na 2 SO 4 without additive and was purged with N 2 gas for 1 h prior to the measurements.A 300 W PLS-SXE 300D Xenon lamp (Beijing Perfectlight) system was applied as the excitation light source equipped with a UV cutoff filter and an IR-cut filter, which was the same light source for the photocatalytic reaction.The Mott-Schottky curves were measured at a frequency of 200, 500, or 800 Hz, respectively. The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction was performed in an on-line CO 2 reduction system (Beijing Perfect Light Technology Co., Ltd.).Typically, 15 mg of the photocatalyst was added into the reaction flask, degassed and purged with CO 2 .A mixture of MeCN and TEOA (110 mL in total) with a volume ratio of 10 to 1 was degassed by CO 2 to remove the dissolved O 2 , and then injected into the reaction flask.The reaction proceeded under the irradiation of a Xe lamp (300 W) with a UV-cut filter and an IR-cut filter (800 nm 420 nm) at room temperature for 10 h.The formed HCOOH was detected by an ion chromatography (930 Compact IC pro, Metrohm) with a Metrosep A supp 5 250/4.0column.A mixture of 3.2 mM Na 2 CO 3 and 1.0 mM NaHCO 3 was used as eluent.The gaseous reaction products were also analyzed using a GC (Agilent 6890A) with a HP-5 capillary column for a flame ionization detector (FID) and a 5A molecular sieve packed column for a thermal conductivity detector (TCD).For the reusability test, after the reaction, the photocatalyst was separated from the reaction medium, repeatedly washed with deionized water twice, and then dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 120 C before the next run.

paper_title: Boosting photocatalytic CO2 reduction over a covalent organic framework decorated with ruthenium nanoparticles
source: Photocatalyst: 15 mg, MeCN/TEOA volume ratio: 10/1, and total solution volume: 110 mL.
context: In summary, the ketoamine-based COF (TpPa-1) loaded with different amounts of Ru NPs, Ru/TpPa-1, was employed in the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 using TEOA as the sacrificial agent upon visible-light irradiation for the first time.All Ru/TpPa-1 photocatalysts show significantly enhanced activities for CO 2 reduction compared to the parent TpPa-1, giving the maximum HCOOH production rate of 108.8 mol g cat -1 h -1 over 3.0 wt Ru/TpPa-1 and competitive with some representative MOF-based photocatalysts under similar conditions.The introduction of Ru NPs can not only enhance the visible-light absorption but also facilitate the photo-generated charge transfer and restrain the recombination of photo-generated charges efficiently.This study demonstrates the great potential of COFs as a platform for effectively photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.Although the activity of Ru/TpPa-1 is still not satisfied, considering the availability of different organic linkers and the possibility to modulate the composition, structure, and properties of COFs, high-efficient COFs-based photocatalysts for the reduction of CO 2 can be developed in the future.And the present strategy provides some guidance in the development of more efficiently heterogeneous photocatalysts for CO 2 reduction.
